definition[0]: to laugh at someone or something and try to make them look stupid by saying unkind things about them or by copying them
example[0]: Opposition MPs mocked the government’s decision.
example[2]: It’s easy for you to mock, but we put a lot of work into this play.
definition[1]: to make something seem completely useless
example[3]: Violent attacks like this mock the peace process.
definition[2]: to laugh at and say unkind things about a person, institution, belief etc, to show that you do not have a high opinion of them. Mock is a formal word – in everyday English people usually say make fun of
example[4]: The press mocked his attempts to appeal to young voters.
example[5]: She was mocked by other pupils in her class.
example[6]: You shouldn’t mock the afflicted!  (=you should not make fun of people who cannot help having problems – used especially ironically, when really you think it is funny too)
definition[3]: to make someone or something seem stupid by making unkind jokes about them
example[7]: Peter didn’t seem to realize that they were making fun of him.
example[8]: It used to be fashionable to make fun of the European Parliament.
definition[4]: to make unkind or funny remarks about someone or something, because they seem stupid or strange
example[9]: I don’t want the other kids to laugh at me.
example[10]: People would laugh at the idea nowadays.
definition[5]: to make someone or something seem silly by making jokes about them, especially in a way that is funny but not really cruel
example[11]: a TV series that regularly poked fun at the government
example[12]: He’s in no position to poke fun at other people’s use of English!
definition[6]: to make unkind remarks that make someone or something seem stupid
example[14]: His ideas were widely ridiculed at the time.
example[15]: Scientists ridiculed him for doubting the existence of the greenhouse effect.
definition[7]: to make remarks that show you think that something is stupid or useless – often used when you think that the people who do this are wrong
example[16]: Some forms of alternative medicine – much derided by doctors – have been shown to help patients.
example[17]: the system that Marxists previously derided as ‘bourgeois democracy’
definition[8]: not real, but intended to be very similar to a real situation, substance etc
definition[9]: used to show that an attitude or feeling is pretended, not real
definition[10]: copying a particular style, especially a style of building
